title: Facial Lentigo Maligna Melanoma
diagnosis_topic: Lentigo Maligna Melanoma of the Cheek – Oncologic Resection & Reconstruction
setup_script: “A 74-year-old woman is referred by her dermatologist for a pigmented patch on her left lateral cheek. She first noticed it two years ago, but over the last six months it has grown darker and slightly larger. She has no prior biopsies or relevant past medical history. What would you like to do next?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for additional history
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient reports gradual enlargement, no pain, no prior melanoma or family history. No immunosuppression.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests vitals and exam
dynamic_flow.reply: “Vitals are normal. Exam reveals a 1.3 cm irregular pigmented macule on the lateral cheek anterior to the tragus. No palpable nodes.”
“Pathology shows invasive lentigo maligna melanoma, Breslow depth 0.9 mm, non-ulcerated, BRAF negative.”
“According to AJCC 8th edition, this is T1a disease.”
“Sentinel lymph node biopsy is optional for depth 0.8–1.0 mm. Patient is medically fit.”
“What surgical margins would you recommend for this lesion?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends wide local excision with 1 cm margin
dynamic_flow.reply: “How would you balance oncologic clearance with cosmetic and functional considerations?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proposes staged excision or Mohs
dynamic_flow.reply: “How would you coordinate care for this patient?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident describes multidisciplinary plan (Mohs, plastic surgery)
If resident describes reconstruction (local advancement/rotation flap)
dynamic_flow.reply: “How would you protect the facial nerve branches during reconstruction?”
“How will you follow this patient after surgery?”
“Please provide a concise summary of your management and counseling for this patient.”

critical_decision_points: Obtain a full-thickness biopsy to establish Breslow depth.
Correctly stage melanoma using AJCC 8th edition.
Choose margin-controlled excision (Mohs or staged excision) in cosmetically sensitive zones.
Coordinate multidisciplinary care (dermatology, Mohs surgery, plastics, pathology).
Provide clear surveillance and counseling plan.

anchors.description: Fails to obtain tissue diagnosis or misinterprets staging.
Obtains biopsy and basic staging, misses optional SLNB discussion.
Accurately interprets pathology, stages correctly, discusses SLNB appropriately.
Proposes wide local excision without consideration of cosmesis.
Proposes excision but lacks structured plan for margins and reconstruction.
Logical plan with appropriate staging, multidisciplinary approach, and reconstruction.
Disorganized, unclear plan, no patient counseling.
Communicates steps but omits cosmetic/functional considerations.
Clear, structured explanation including risks, surveillance, and patient-centered concerns.
Incorrect margins or inappropriate excision method.
Basic knowledge of excision but vague on technical details.
Excellent understanding of margin-controlled excision, reconstructive techniques, and nerve preservation.
Ignores multidisciplinary input or patient factors.
Engages full team, counsels on cosmetic/functional outcomes, and maintains patient-centered approach.
